caption: Small, very manageable, well-curated exhibit. Tarsila de Aguia exhibit is amazing, especially florals, portraits, and cityscapes.

Unpleasant experience with the rude staff at the garderobe. They still had plenty of space but did not want to accept our clothes. And they didn‚Äôt just refused it but were very ‚ÄúFrench‚Äù about it.
I saw the exposition about Monet's brother and the use of painting dedicated to textil in painting. It was really interesting !

Visited during the Gertrude Stein & Pablo Picasso exhibition. Good expo, although rather small (only two rooms, and only a few Picasso paintings), which did raise the question of value-for-money (EUR 15).

Enjoyed the Picasso /Stein exhibit, creatively depicting the influences they had on one another. Relatively small and easily visited museum just outside the jardin du Luxembourg where you should allow time for a walk

The exhibition is small; there is not enough time to visit the museum.  and also, they are not included in the Paris Card Museum.  the price is slightly higher than others, and the exhibition area is small.  Because of this, I lowered the score.  and since I bought a Paris Museum Card, but they are not included, I bought a new ticket at the box office.
Interesting museum; we saw an exhibit devoted to the Olympics. There is no permanent collection, so check current offering before going.
Great collection. Nicely curated. Leon Monet‚Äôs art collection of Impressionist painters, Japanese prints. Early drawings of his brother Claude and more.
It was a great exhibition but their organizational structure was incredibly lacking

14 euros and 45 minutes later, instead of being energized, I was mentally tired.  Gertrude Stein and Pablo Picasso, a very small exhibition. Should 've been a free exhibition. Do not expect to see but a handful of Picasso' s work. Three photos are not Picasso' s work.

The museum exhibits impressionist art connected to Leon Monet, the art collector and brother of Claude Monet. The exhibition is not large, but it is just convenient for a one-time visit. The presentation was well suited in French and in English. I used the audio guide that was available with no extra charge. The entrance fee was 15,50 euros. This exhibition lasts to 16th of July. The museum shop is also good.

Nice small museum giving park goers an alternative to the sometimes adverse Parisian weather (and it has nice toilets!). Really enjoyed the Vivian Maier photo exhibit, loved her work. It‚Äôs recommended to buy your tickets online but this was an impromptu stop for me and only had to wait about 10 minutes (not a big deal compared to other Paris museum waits). Recommend visiting if the current exhibit is to your liking

A small east-to-digest museum on the edge of the Luxembourg Gardens. During the hot summer months it can be a welcome respite from the sun or a bit of art before taking the kids to the Gardens where they can run and play. There is a small gift shop featuring books and reasonably priced postcards related to the exhibition which is accessible without needing to pay for entrance. Prices range from free to ‚Ç¨14, depending on ages.
Excellent exhibitions, best viewed in a guided tour offered for a reasonable price by the museum staff either in French or in English a few times a week.
great tarsila exhibition, but unfortunately all texts are only in french and there is no english catalogue :(
Very interesting exhibition. The venue is very small so you can walk through the exhibits in about an hour.
The exhibition Picasso-Stein is excellent. I also recommend the "Chocolat Chaud" and the "Mont-Blanc" at Angelina's caf√© of the museum, a real delight!
very nice expo on Gertrude Stein and Picasso
Often has good exhibitions, but depends what is on at the time

No line up, easy and quick get in, and friendly staff, but still a rather underwhelming experience. The match exhibition was very small, just one hall basically. You'd be done in 15 minutes even including reading the signs. It was very expensive at a steep entrance ticket price of 14 Euro for what it has to offer. The curation of items regarding the history of sports was rather poor in my opinion. Would not recommend.

I just saw the Leon Monet's private art collection (Claude's brother) at the Museum du Luxembourg.  Leon's "claim to fame" was his work in creating synthetic paint.  Research shows that almost every Impression piece of the 19th century was done using synthetic paint!  The art pieces include those of Claude Monet, Augusta Renoir, Camille Pissarro, and others.  For this exhibition, the art was curated from museums in France (Orsay, Rouen and more), Scotland, private collections and more.  This collection runs until 16 July 2023. A full price ticket is 14 Euro.  Anyone 26 years and under has free entry.
the exposition wasn‚Äôt that good but the place is cute, some interesting pieces

Match: A Missed Opportunity in Sports and Design  The exhibition "Match" attempts to intertwine the worlds of sports and design, promising an great experience for visitors. However, despite its lofty ambitions, "Match" falls short of expectations, particularly considering its steep price and brevity.  One of the exhibition's glaring flaws is its failure to fully capitalize on its potential and lack of immersivity. Given its timing to coincide with the Paris Olympics and the influx of tourists, "Match" should have been a grander affair. Instead, visitors are met with a disappointingly limited selection of artifacts, none of which are interactive or touchable.  The exhibition's thematic scope is another missed opportunity. Rather than delving into the rich history of sports design, from ancient Greece to contemporary sportswear brands like Lacoste and Adidas, "Match" only scratches the surface. There's a notable absence of exploration into the evolution of sports equipment or the origins of iconic sports like football.  Furthermore, the inclusion of seemingly unrelated elements, such as photographs of Afghan women in burkas, feels disjointed and lacks relevance to the exhibition's theme. The reliance on QR codes and YouTube videos for additional content only adds to the frustration, detracting from the immersive experience promised.  In essence, "Match" fails to deliver on its promise of an engaging exploration of sports and design. With its lackluster presentation and missed opportunities for deeper exploration, it's a exhibition that leaves much to be desired. A reimagining of "Match" in a larger, more interactive space is sorely needed to do justice to its compelling subject matter.
The Brazilian artist was tip top but it's a temporary exhibition...

The show about Picasso and Gertrude Stein is remarkable. It‚Äôs more than that it‚Äôs about every art form, and how the way they deconstructed the formality of the previous century affected dance and music, as well as sculpture, writing, and painting. And it‚Äôs such a beautiful museum.

I love this quick museum, which pairs perfectly with a walk in the Jardin du Luxembourg. The high quality exhibits are frequently refreshed, so one can return often.  Pro-tip: if you go in the warm months, be sure to also go around the back to the separate Orangerie (an actual working greenhouse) where they have free art exhibits when the plants are moved outside.

I‚Äôve just been to the new picasso exibition in this museum and this was seriously disappointing. Paying 14 euros is a lot for just one room of exibition, plus they didn‚Äôt have tranation for almost anything. Some few things were translated poorly and made little sense in english. I feel like I wasted my money, I should have spent it on the picasso museum instead, or in anything else really. I could have eaten a nice cr√©pe with that money instead. I love Picasso and though this was going to be better. They also don‚Äôt have free entrances for under 26.
You cannot be serious. This price for such a small exposition ? Pure robbery. Outrageous
Moderate storytelling and really small exhibition (45m). The pricing is off: there are a lot friendlier priced museums with better collections.

This is a wonderful museum.  Perfectly intimate.   Watch for up coming exhibits.  While there, I saw show by recently discovered photography of an American woman named Maier.  A photographer with an eye and talent for faces with great character.  Photos circa 1940-1960.
Great expo Stein and Picasso.

They always have interesting exhibits and unique themes. The signage is in French only. The audio guide was confusing as in some cases there were two sets of numbers. I was not sure what one number was referring to. It is very small so you are bumping into people. The restaurant outside is wonderful but pricey. But the content is worth all that.

I just saw a lovely exposition that I was unfortunately not able to fully understand, as all passages and explanations were written only in French. I feel like Paris, being the hub it is, and the museum itself being one of the biggest attractions of this city, it would warrant a translation at least in English. The art itself and the curation was lovely and I wish I didn‚Äôt have to use my high school French to try and under :)

Saw the <> exhibition, showcasing the works of pioneering female artists from the early 20th century and it was phenomenal. Wonderfully organised, expansive yet succinct. 100% recommend if you have any interest in the history of female or queer artists

small, intimate museum--a real contrast to the Louvre.  There was an excellent exhibition on women artists--dancers, writers, painters--in the Roaring 20's.  Check out what's on  exhibit before you come to Paris.
Honestly, too expensive for what it is. Paid full price to see maybe 2 interesting things, and finished the tour in 15 minutes.
The exhibition space was amazing, they were showing Leon Monets collection when I was there. The garden grounds were lovely to walk through.
